Core Package¶

l2r.core.controller¶

class l2r.core.controller.SimulatorController(ip='0.0.0.0', port='16000', quiet=False, sim_version='ArrivalSim-linux-0.7.0-cmu4', start_container=False, image_name='arrival-sim', container_name='racing-sim', sim_path=False, user='ubuntu')[source]¶

Bases: object

This class is used to communicate with the simulator which is accessible via Websocket. The methods in this class allow one to change the position of the vehicle, set the map, reset the map, change the settings (such as turning the camera on), etc.

Parameters

  • ip (str) – IP address of the simulator

  • port (str) – port to connect to

  • quiet (boolean) – flag to show print statements about changes being made to the simulator

  • sim_version (str) – version of the simulator

  • start_container (boolean) – start simulator container. Assumes unix-based os

  • image_name (str) – name of the simulator’s docker image

reset_level()[source]¶

Resets the map to its default configuration. This does not reset the vehicle parameters, but it does set the vehicle to it’s default pose.

  • rot (dict) – rotation of the vehicle in degrees with keys [yaw, pitch, roll]

  • veh_id (int) – identifier of the vehicle, defaults to 0

start_simulator()[source]¶

Starts the simulator container, and briefly waits. If a connection error occurs, you may need to increase this delay.

l2r.core.templates¶

Note

The templates module provides useful abstract classes which we recommend using for compatability with the RacingEnv.

class l2r.core.templates.AbstractAgent(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: abc.ABC

Abstract agent class. A potentially useful template for racing agents.

abstract create_env()[source]¶

Instantiate a racing environment.

abstract select_action()[source]¶

Select an action to take.

class l2r.core.templates.AbstractInterface(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: abc.ABC

Abstract simulator interface to receive data from the simulator.

abstract get_data()[source]¶

This method is used to return the most up-to-date information from the interface.

abstract reset()[source]¶

Used to reset the interface, often to clear existing data.

abstract start()[source]¶

The start method is used to start communication with the simulator.

class l2r.core.templates.AbstractReward(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: abc.ABC

Abstract reward class. It is recommended that new reward policies follow this template so that they are compatible with the RacingEnv.

abstract get_reward(state, **kwargs)[source]¶

Return the reward for the provided state.

Parameters

state (varies) – the current environment state

abstract reset()[source]¶

Reset the reward policy.

set_track(inside_path, outside_path, centre_path, car_dims)[source]¶

Store the track and vehicle information as class variables. This is useful for evaluating the reward based on the position of the vehicle.

Parameters

  • inside_path (matplotlib.Path) – ENU coordinates of the inside track boundary

  • outside_path (matplotlib.Path) – ENU coordinates of the outside track boundary

  • centre_path (matplotlib.Path) – ENU coordinates of the track’s centerline

  • car_dims (list) – dimensions of the vehicle in meters: [length, width]

l2r.core.tracker¶

class l2r.core.tracker.ProgressTracker(n_indices, inner_track, outer_track, centerline, car_dims, obs_delay, max_timesteps, not_moving_ct, debug=False)[source]¶

Bases: object

Progress tracker for the vehicle. This class serves to track the number of laps that the vehicle has completed and how long each one took. It also evaluates for termination conditions.

Parameters

  • n_indices (int) – number of indicies of the centerline of the track

  • inner_track (matplotlib.path) – path of the inner track boundary

  • outer_track (matplotlib.path) – path of the outer track boundary

  • centerline (numpy.array) – path of the centerline

  • car_dims (list) – dimensions of the vehicle in meters [len, width]

  • obs_delay (float) – time delay between a RacingEnv action and observation

  • max_timesteps (int) – maximum number of timesteps in an episode

  • not_moving_ct (int) – maximum number of vehicle can be stationary before being considered stuck

  • debug (boolean) – debugging print statement flag

append_metrics(info)[source]¶

Calculate metrics and append to info

Parameters

info (dict) – episode information

Returns

info with appended metrics

Return type

dict

check_lap_completion(shifted_idx, now)[source]¶

Check if we completed a lap. To prevent vehicles from oscillating near the start line, the vehicle must first cross the halfway mark of the track. If the vehicle has cross the halfway mark, we then check if the vehicle has crossed the index that it started at. If the vehicle crosses multiple indicies in one time step when this happens, the lap’s end time is a linear interpolation between the time of the prior update and the current time

Parameters

  • shifted_idx (int) – index on the track’s centerline which the vehicle is nearest to shifted based on the starting index on the track

  • now (float) – time of the update

is_complete()[source]¶

Determine if the episode is complete due to finishing 3 laps, remaining in the same position for too long (stuck), exceeding the maximum number of timestepsor, or going out-of-bounds. If all 3 laps were successfully completed, the total time is also returned.

Returns

complete, info which includes metrics if successful

Return type

boolean, str, list of floats, float

reset(start_idx)[source]¶

Reset the tracker for the next episode.

Parameters

start_idx (int) – index on the track’s centerline which the vehicle is nearest to

update(idx, e, n, u, yaw, ac, bp)[source]¶

Update the tracker based on current position. The tracker also keeps track of the yaw, brake pressure, centerline displacement, and calculates the offical metrics for the environment.

Parameters

  • idx (int) – index on the track’s centerline which the vehicle is nearest to

  • e (float) – east coordinate

  • n (float) – north coordinate

  • u (float) – up coordinate

  • yaw (float) – vehicle heading, in radians

  • ac (numpy.array) – directional acceleration, shape of (3,)

  • bp (numpy.array) – brake pressure, per wheel, shape of (4,)
